title: RAF workman stole fuel from a 1,000mph Tornado fighter to use in his van
text:
RAF workman stole fuel from a 1,000mph Tornado fighter to use in his van RAF workman stole fuel from a 1,000mph Tornado fighter to use in his van AN RAF workman stole a mighty 1,000mph TORNADO warplane's fuel - and put it in his VAN. PUBLISHED: 09:20, Tue, Feb 21, 2017 | UPDATED: 09:28, Tue, Feb 21, 2017 ARCHANT Steve Coakley stole a mighty 1,000mph Tornado warplane's fuel 
Steve Coakley, 42, was shot down after RAF cops were tipped off that he was systematically stealing waste aviation juice from frontline Tornado fighter-bombers. 
Coakley, of Wymondham, near Norwich, was filling his Volkswagen van, a compressor and his girlfriend's motor with fuel from RAF Marham, west Norfolk. Related articles Barnsley petrol station worker mowed down for confronting fuel thief 
The crooked contractor yesterday admitted theft by employee after being hauled into court. 
Josephine Jones, prosecuting, said that police got an anonymous tip that fighter fuel was being used in private vehicles. 
As a result CCTV cameras were set up and a surveillance operation launched. 
Coakley was collared after footage showed a van being filled up on November 11, King's Lynn magistrates' court heard. ARCHANT RAF Marham, west Norfolk 
Police found fuel stored in three jerrycans in his van as well as a 500-litre container in his garden after they scoured his home. 
Miss Jones told JPs: "This was not just one vehicle - it was a number of vehicles with other parties. 
"It appears that his involvement was much greater, he had been doing it for a couple of years. ARCHANT Steve Coakley, 42, was shot down after RAF cops were tipped off 
"His police interview covered a shorter period of two months, between September and November last year." 
Coakley plundered fuel worth £660, the court heard. 
The villain's vehicles were signed over to Her Majesty's Revenue and Customs, including a seven and a half ton lorry, after he dodged paying tax - making a total loss of £4,500. 
Ruth Johnson, defending Coakley, said: "He made a full and frank admission and admitted that it was on and off and not a regular occurrence. 
"He is a civil individual now. 
"He is not employed by RAF Marham and is no longer with his girlfriend. 
"This incident has put him significantly out of pocket." 
Chairman of the bench, Simmy Potter, gave jobless Coakley a 12-month community order and told him to do 50 hours unpaid work. 11 things you need to know about NATO Tue, February 14, 2017 NATO - The North Atlantic Treaty Organization is an intergovernmental military alliance based on the North Atlantic Treaty which was signed on 4th April 1949. He was also ordered to pay an £85 victim surcharge and £85 costs. 
Coakley is not working at the moment and is being forced to live off income he receives from rental properties he owns, the court heard. The swing wing Tornado is a veteran of RAF strikes against enemy forces in bitter wars in Iraq, Afghanistan, Libya and Syria.
